description.narrative: Strengthening targeted national capacities to improve decision-making and mainstreaming global environmental obligations into national development priorities

activity-description.narrative: Decision on exact municipality will be made by the end of this year

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1. # of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or subnational level 2. # of countries with legal, policy and institutional frameworks in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems 3. # of direct project beneficiaries 4. Systems for data and information are strengthened and Rio Convention obligations are mainstreamed into sectoral plans that include targets to measure progress toward achieving global environmental obligations 5. A data and information management system is developed and tested that allows data, information, and knowledge to be tracked through creation to informing policy and plans 6. Stakeholders are trained on best practice skills to use data and information for planning and decision-making on the global environment 7. A long-term training programme is developed and institutionalized on Rio Convention mainstreaming based on lessons learned from the project’s learning-by-doing workshops and related exercises 8. Inter-ministerial and inter-directorate communication, coordination, and collaboration is strengthened 9. Non-state public consultative mechanisms developed and integrated into official planning and decision-making processes 10. Operational by-laws are developed to improve and legitimize Rio Convention mainstreaming into sector development plans. 11. New and improved best practice approaches to reconcile sectoral priorities with Rio Convention obligations are integrated into the decision-making framework 12. A sustainable financing strategy is developed for the national environmental information system 13. Raised awareness of the contribution of global environmental values to socio-economic development 14. Education modules on the importance of the global environment developed and English language courses held 15. Collectively and over the

comment.narrative:
1. 0 2. The baseline of this indicator is qualitatively measured as inadequate, reflected by the inadequacy of existing policy and legal instruments to guarantee the realization of Rio Convention obligations. 3. 0 4. - Strategies, policies and programmes for environmental conservation are inadequate. - The existing institutional structures and mechanisms for data and information management are out of date and hinder by limited data sharing. 5. Data creation and management remains a major challenge for Timor-Leste. 6. Systems for data and information management are outdated and inadequate. 7. Decision-makers and government staff have limited technical skills
8. There is limited inter and intra agency coordination 9. There is a weak legislative base for coordination and information sharing of research activities 10. Strategies, policies and programmes for environmental conservation are inadequate 11. There is limited availability of funding 12. Existing government and private sector budgets for environmental management are very limited 13. There have been notable observations by stakeholders that low level of awareness among policy makers is a key challenge to promote all environmental issues in TL – particularly for finalizing national policies, plans, strategies and also for allocation of resources in relevant ministries and agencies. 14. Government stakeholders and the general public remain unaware or unconcerned about the contribution of the Rio Conventions to meeting and satisfying local and national socio-economic priorities 15. Awareness of Rio Convention mainstreaming is limited, and stakeholders do not fully appreciating the value of conserving the global environment. 16. During PPG consultations, limited English skills were identified as a major limitation to meeting obligations under the Rio Conventions.

1) Establishment of Timor-Leste NEIS -Web-Based Platform under the National Directorate of Environmental Education & Information-Secretary of State for Environment 2) Signature of Agreement on Information Sharing, data & information management among key Ministries, CSO, Agencies, Academia. 3) Best Practices & Guidelines for improved M & E and compliance are started to be formulated 4) Training on best practice skills to use data & information is conducted 5) An inter-directorate coordination group is established and inter-directorate coordination meetings are conducted 6) Working Group meetings are convened and agreement on information and data sharing is signed 7) 1) National Action Plan-NAP for land degradation finalized, submitted and approved by Council of Ministers; 2) National Adaptation Plan-NAP Framework under Climate Change is approved by Council of Ministries 8) Programs and/or plans for mainstreaming exercise are selected by stakeholder 9) Survey on Rio Conventions understanding conducted 10) Awareness Raising workshops are conducted 11) Panel Discussion on global environmental issues is conducted through TV & Radio program 12) PSAs are produced & broadcast on national TV & Radio 13) A set of Environmental Awareness Module for Secondary Schools is developed 14) Social Media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter) on Environmental & Rio Conventions are created 15) Three English language courses are conducted

1) Design for NEIS is prepared. Systems and processes for managing key environmental data and information will be updated once the NEIS is established in Q2 of 2022. 2) The project is hiring a consultant to develop Environmental Indicators to be incorporated into M&E processes by Q2 of 2022. 3) A draft Institutional arrangements and inter-agency agreement on information sharing have been prepared, to be signed before the launch of the NEIS. 4) Training exercises have been planned to begin in January to June 2022. 5) During project inception and project board meetings, it was decided or agreed to support and reinvigorate existing or previously established national inter-directorate coordination groups, instead of creating new groups. The working groups are including Climate Change Working Group, Biodiversity, and Land-degradation working groups, and other Thematic Working Groups, comprised of directorates from relevant ministries, International Agencies, NGOs, and INGOs. During 2020-2021 the project supported and organized different existing working group meetings, workshops, and conferences, including (i) Climate Change Working Group meetings; (ii) Inter-directorate coordination meetings conducted during NAP formulation; and (iii) Small group-technical meetings held with key directorates during the covid- 19 state of emergency period. 6) Two technical training workshops were conducted in Q1 and Q2 on various topics include planning, coordination, Monitoring and Evaluation, and reporting, participated by technical staff from relevant key ministries. The training was organized together with the SSE and Planning, Monitoring, and Evaluation Unit-UPMA under the Office of the Prime Minister. 7) In May 2021, Climate Change Policy was tabled in the Council of Ministers by the Secretary of State for Environment and Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs. The Council of Ministers reviewed, discussed, and approved the policy on 22 December 2021 8) The project is providing technical assistance to the government to review and study existing policy/ regulatory framework, strategic documents, national plans, and reports related to Rio Conventions. Priority sectoral development policies, legislation, plans, and/or program have been identified for pilot mainstreaming of Rio Conventions. Five possible options were prepared including; Option 1: Improve sectoral mainstreaming of Rio Conventions. It focuses on establishing standard operating procedures for reviewing new information and guidance from the various Rio Conventions and identifying entry points in existing sectoral processes. Option 2: Establish draft regulations and implementation guidelines for community forestry. This could benefit community forestry for climate change mitigation and adaptation, preserving biodiversity, and combating deforestation. The right kinds of laws and regulations are seen as a key part of establishing an enabling environment for community forestry. Option 3: Encourage Tara Bandu in Natural Resource Management. Tara Bandu is important under the Constitution, and it’s also relevant to all three of the Rio Conventions. Therefore, the third option is to conduct a project to create the enabling conditions for approaches to implementing the Rio Conventions that incorporate custom systems. Option 4: Climate proofing infrastructure investments. The fourth option would be to draft regulations and related materials for climate-proofing investments in infrastructure. There would likely be synergies between this effort and the NAP support project that will be implemented with GCF support Option 5: Establish regulations to support ecosystem-based adaptation. Implementing EbA approaches is a way to advance all 3 Rio Conventions, and there are also likely to be synergies with the NAP project that will be developed for GCF funding. 9) Initial 8 knowledge surveys done in 8 municipalities with the total number of respondents around 300: • 80% satisfied with awareness-raising activities; • 90% got new info on Rio conventions 10) Under the public awareness campaign, the project conducted 19 sub-national workshops covering 8 municipalities and 2 Tara Bandu events covering 2 municipalities. The workshops and Tara Bandu ritual involving local leaders and activists (local community leaders, traditional leaders, government authorities, youth activists) were attended by approximately 1,500 participants. The topics in crosshair included dissemination of Rio Conventions, the environmental base law, sensitization of biodiversity conservation, dialog with communities, and reviving the local customary law of Tara Bandu. 11) Through the LVG with the TLJA, the project produced and broadcasted on national television 4 talk shows on environment issues and Rio Conventions, which involved the private sector, national government authorities, civil society, academia, youth groups, and community leaders 12) 2 articles were published on national media (Neon Metin and Dili Post), 2 Tara Bandu events were broadcast on national TVs (TVTL and GMN TV). 13) Education modules on the importance of the global environment (environment curricula) have been completed. It will be used by the National Institution for Public Administration to train newly recruited civil service employees 14) More than 12 articles have been published on national media and Social Media (Facebook and Twitter) and shared widely). 15) 3 sets of English training courses were held with 75 stakeholders, (53% are women) from relevant ministries including; Ministry of Agriculture & Fisheries; Ministry of State Administration; Secretary of State for Environment; Ministry of Public Works; Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Tourism; Ministry of Health; and Ministry of Finance.

1) A participatory gender analysis conducted and gender mainstreamed in project components. 2) Rio Conventions curriculum for GoTL officials designed. 3) At least 20 master trainers of INAP trained on the new curriculum. 4) At least 25 GoTL officials trained on language proficiency. 5) Baseline prepared for an integrated environmental database management system. 6) At least 20 national journalists trained on environmental reporting. 7) Targeted villages in 2 municipalities supported with implementation of Tara Bandu. 8) Public Service Announcements (PSAs) on Rio Conventions designed. 9) “Green School” and Dissemination of Environmental Law to Sucos (villages) in 4 municipalities - Covalima, Viqueque, Manufahi and Bobonaro.

1) Participatory Gender analysis conducted and mainstreamed into project components through an IC contract 2) Draft Environmental Curriculum designed and consulted with key stakeholders through validation workshop and consultation meetings 3) Due to time constraints, Training for Master Trainers or ToT will be carried out in 2020 4) 25 technical staff from various key ministries participated in a 6 (six) months English Course including; 1) Ministry of Agriculture & Fisheries; 2) Secretary of State for Environment; 3) Ministry of Commerce, Trade, Industry and Turism; 4) Ministry of State Administration; 5) Ministry of Public Works 5) Baseline preparation for Data Base management system is in the progress, will be completed by February 2020 6)Environmental Journalism training for 20 national journalists from Print, Electronic and On line media done within 5 days in October 7) Tara bandu and environment campaign done in Sucos Vatubou, Maubara and Suco Metamali Liquica 8) PSA on Rio Conventions in the form of Pamphlets, Billoards, etc designed, PSA for Radio & TV will be designed in 2020 9) Green School & Dissemination of Environmental Law done in Technical/Vocational School of Akadiruhun Same-Manufahi. Green School activity for Viqueque, Covalima & Bobonaro has been re-scheduled for January 2020 due to school holiday.

1) Feasibility study on an improved electronic platform for information-sharing conducted 2) Undertake stakeholder meetings to agree on institutional reforms 3) Training plans are approved, trainings are launched 4) Support Climate Change Working Group meetings, workshops, and conferences 5) Review/Study of legal framework limiting Rio Conventions is conducted 6) Learn-by-doing workshops to reconcile policy and legal weaknesses and gaps is conducted 7) Appropriate by-laws and operational guidance to mainstream Rio Conventions are formulated/drafted 8) Workshops or meetings on environmental awareness raising conducted (LoA with SSE) 9) 2000 brochures on Rio Conventions are printed and distributed 10) 2 articles on Rio Conventions & Environmental Published 11) Initial survey to be conducted during awareness raising activities 12) 7 Modules on environment curricula for civil servants are completed 13) Rio conventions and CCCD’s project related activities published on social media 14) 2 sets of English training courses (Basic & Level 2) held

1) Feasibility study has been postponed to 2021 2) Stakeholders meetings conducted. A draft agreement on information/data sharing within relevant institutions academia and civil society has been prepared. 3) Training has been delayed 4) 2 Climate Change working group meetings held participated by different stakeholders; Inter-directorate coordination meetings conducted during NAP formulation; 4 small-group technical meetings held with key directorates 5) Current policies and legal framework to identify weaknesses and gaps limiting Rio Conventions and gender responsive climate change priorities are reviewed. 6) The workshop Postponed for 2021 7) Formulation of by-laws & operational guidance are ongoing to be completed in the 1st quarter of 2021 8) 20 Public Awareness Raising Workshops on Rio Conventions & Environment in 18 Sucos of 9 municipalities. 9) 0 Printing of Brochures on Rio Conventions 10) 4 articles published in national media & radio on linkages between the global environment and socio-economic issues for publication in popular literature 11) Initial 8 knowledge surveys done in 8 municipalities with total number of respondents around 300. Summary: 1) 80% satisfy with awareness raising activities; 2) 90% got new info on Rio conventions 12) 7 Modules were presented stakeholders and validated and 20 technical staff Training on the use of modules were conducted 13) 7 posts on FB and twitter + several posts on Secretary of State for Environments FB and Environment - Tara bandu activities broadcasted on national TV (RTTL) and on RRTL’s YouTube 14) 2 sets of English training conducted

Component 1. Target: 1) Establishment and launching of Timor-Leste Environment Information System-Web Based Platform under National Directorate of Environmental Education & Information-Secretary of State for Environment 2) Signature of Agreement on Information Sharing, data & information management among key Ministries, CSO, Agencies, Academia 3) Best Practices & Guidelines of improved monitoring & compliance are formulated and piloted 4) Training on best practice skills to use data & information is conducted
Component 2. Target: 1) Inter-directorate coordination group is established 2) Inter-directorate coordination meetings are conducted 3) Cooperative agreements are signed 4) Training workshop to improve coordination and collaboration are conducted 5) Working Group meetings are convened 6) Agreement on information and data sharing is signed
Component 3. Target: 1) National Action Plan -CLD is revised and submitted for approval; Renewable Energy Policy is revised and submitted for approval. 2) Updated codes, laws & texts are distributed 3) Programs and/or plan for mainstreaming exercise are selected by stakeholder 4) Workshop is conducted 5) feasibility study completed and piloted 6) Training is conducted 7) Environmental Road Map is formulated & validated 8) Resource Mobilization Strategy is finalized & approved
Component 4. Target: 1) Survey on Rio Conventions understanding is conducted 2) Awareness Raising workshops are conducted 3) Panel Discussion on global environmental issues is conducted through TV & Radio program 4) Training on MEA legislative mainstreaming is conducted 5) Brochures on Rio Conventions are printed & distributed 6) PSAs are produced & broadcasted on national TV & Radio 7) A set of Environmental Awareness Module for Secondary Schools is developed 8) Data & Info on Environment & Rio Conventions are disseminated widely 9) Social Media (Facebook, Instagram, twitter) on Environmental & Rio Conventions are created 10) Three English language courses are conducted
